creator: rosenbach@seninn.verwalt-berlin.de
text:
OS is Tru64 UNIX 4.0E patchkit 4.

mod_status is compiled and enabled (and works).

I introduced (as stated in ./manual/mod/mod_status.html#extendedstatus)

    <Location /server-status>
    SetHandler server-status
    Order Deny,Allow
    Deny from all
    Allow from myhost.foo.com
    </Location>

But other hosts than the given one are allowed to see the server status!

BTW: in my case "myhost" and the other host were connected via some proxy-
server (which is NOT myhost).
So, in my point of view, NONE of them should have been honored given the config 
above ... ???

Best regards, Martin Rosenbach

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
The handler doesn't know about access restrictions, these will be caught much
earlier. It's very likely that your problem is just a configuration issue, i.e.
you're overriding the access restriction somewhere (alternatively you may have a
DNS problem). Is it possible?

Meanwhile, I changed configuration to

<Location http://ab.cd.ef.gh/server-status> and
<Location http://webserver.domain.my/server-status>,

as stated in ./manual/mod/core.html#location

Nothing better. BTW: DNS is working.

So long, Martin Rosenbach
creator: rosenbach@seninn.verwalt-berlin.de

text:
<Location http://webserver.domain.my/server-status> is useless since you have an
origin server, not a proxy!
I didn't doubt, that your DNS is working :). I just wanted to check if the proxy
doesn't resolve to the allowed hostname ...

However, please search your configuration for other order, deny and allow
directives. Satisfy Any may also "break" your access restriction.

What happens if you do the following?

<Location /server-status>
 Order ...
 Deny ..
 Allow ...
 Satisfy All
</Location>
